Sure, here's a fun kayak polo training session that takes about 1.5 hours and can be done with around 15 people:

Warm-Up (15 minutes)

* Begin with a 5-10 minute light paddle to warm up the muscles.
* Follow with 5 minutes of stretching to increase flexibility and reduce the risk of injury.

Drills (45 minutes)

* Pass and Shoot: Divide the group into pairs and have them practice passing the ball back and forth while paddling towards the goal. The passer should lead the receiver so that they have an open shot at the goal. Have the pairs take turns shooting at the goal from different angles.
* Blocking: Have the group pair up and practice blocking each other's shots. The blocker should use their kayak and paddle to prevent the shooter from scoring.
* Scrimmage: Divide the group into two teams and have them play a scrimmage with one ball and two goals. Allow the teams to practice passing, shooting, and blocking. Switch the teams' positions after 10 minutes.

Game Play (30 minutes)

* Set up two goals on opposite ends of the playing area.
* Divide the group into two teams of seven players each.
* Play a game of kayak polo with two 15-minute halves.
* Encourage the teams to practice their passing, shooting, and blocking skills.
* Allow substitutions as needed.

Cool-Down (15 minutes)

* End with a 5-10 minute light paddle to cool down the muscles.
* Follow with 5 minutes of stretching to improve flexibility and reduce the risk of injury.

Note: Make sure to establish clear boundaries for the playing area and to set rules for safe play. It's also recommended to wear appropriate safety gear, including a properly fitting life jacket, and to play in a calm and safe water environment.

Sure, here's a good whitewater kayak training session for total beginners on class 2 whitewater:

Warm-Up (10-15 minutes)

* Begin with a 5-10 minute light paddle to warm up the muscles.
* Follow with 5 minutes of stretching to increase flexibility and reduce the risk of injury.

Safety Briefing (10-15 minutes)

* Cover basic safety information, including wearing a properly fitting life jacket and helmet, how to perform a wet exit, and how to swim in whitewater.
* Discuss the importance of communication and staying together as a group.
* Go over hand signals and basic river rescue techniques.

Flatwater Skills Practice (30-45 minutes)

* Practice basic paddle strokes, including forward stroke, reverse stroke, draw stroke, and sweep stroke.
* Practice edging and bracing techniques to help maintain balance in moving water.
* Practice wet exits and self-rescue techniques in flatwater.

Class 2 Whitewater Skills Practice (60-90 minutes)

* Begin with a short section of easy class 1 or flatwater to warm up and review skills.
* Practice maneuvering through small waves and eddies in easy class 2 rapids.
* Practice ferrying, or crossing the current, to reach the opposite bank.
* Practice catching and exiting eddies, or calm areas behind rocks, to rest and avoid hazards.
* Practice running small drops and waves in a controlled manner.
* Encourage the group to communicate and work together to navigate the rapids safely.

Cool-Down (10-15 minutes)

* End with a 5-10 minute light paddle to cool down the muscles.
* Follow with 5 minutes of stretching to improve flexibility and reduce the risk of injury.

Note: Make sure to choose an appropriate section of river for the skill level of the kayakers and to always practice safety measures when kayaking in moving water. It's also recommended to wear appropriate safety gear, including a properly fitting life jacket and helmet, and to paddle with a trained instructor or experienced kayaker.

Great question! If the participants already have some basic flatwater skills and you want to focus on the whitewater part, here's a training session that you can use:

Warm-Up (10-15 minutes)

* Begin with a 5-10 minute light paddle to warm up the muscles.
* Follow with 5 minutes of stretching to increase flexibility and reduce the risk of injury.

Safety Briefing (10-15 minutes)

* Review basic safety information, including wearing a properly fitting life jacket and helmet, how to perform a wet exit, and how to swim in whitewater.
* Discuss the importance of communication and staying together as a group.
* Go over hand signals and basic river rescue techniques.

Whitewater Skills Practice (60-90 minutes)

* Start with a section of easy class 2 rapids to warm up and review basic whitewater skills.
* Practice paddling through small waves and eddies, using eddies to rest and avoid hazards, and ferrying to cross the current.
* Practice catching and exiting eddies in faster-moving water and using peel-outs to exit eddies and get back into the current.
* Practice running small drops and waves in a controlled manner, using proper technique to avoid capsizing.
* Practice eddy hopping, or catching one eddy and then quickly moving to the next, to navigate more complex sections of river.
* Encourage the group to communicate and work together to navigate the rapids safely.

Cool-Down (10-15 minutes)

* End with a 5-10 minute light paddle to cool down the muscles.
* Follow with 5 minutes of stretching to improve flexibility and reduce the risk of injury.

Note: Make sure to choose an appropriate section of river for the skill level of the kayakers and to always practice safety measures when kayaking in moving water. It's also recommended to wear appropriate safety gear, including a properly fitting life jacket and helmet, and to paddle with a trained instructor or experienced kayaker.
